did.abstract: Papers of Juris Upatnieks, a University of Michigan scientist who helped to lay the foundations of holography, a photography technique that recreates the recorded objects with all of their three-dimensional optical properties. Collection includes Upatnieks correspondence with American and international scientists and companies, scientific papers, proposals and technical reports, sometimes prepared in collaboration with other scientists, as well as digitized laboratory notebooks and lantern slides illustrating his research on various subjects.

bioghist.p: Juris Upatnieks was born in Riga, Latvia, in 1936. The family immigrated to the United States in 1951. Upatnieks received his Bachelor of Electrical Engineering degree from the University of Akron in 1960 and Master of Science in Engineering, Electrical Engineering degree from the University of Michigan's Institute of Science and Technology in 1965. Between 1960 and 1972 he worked at the University of Michigan Institute of Science and Technology Willow Run Laboratories, where he held positions from Research Assistant to Research Engineer. In 1962 he and the University of Michigan professor of Electrical Engineering and the Willow Run Laboratories Research Associate Emmet Leith recorded the first transmission hologram of a two-dimensional object (a photographic transparency or slide). Leith and Upatnieks published results of their work on holography in Fall 1963, publicizing it as "lensless photography." They continued working on improvement of their technique using newly available laser to achieve coherence of light and clear three-dimensional holographic images. In December 1963 the first three-dimensional object was recorded. Results of their work in this area were presented in 1964 and caused renewed interest to coherent optics, holography, and their practical applications in medicine, optics, data storage, airline safety, space science, the military, the arts, among other fields. Upatnieks reflected on reviving the field of Holography in his work "Development of Holography: from November 1962 to January 1965" (1965)

Between 1973 and 1993 Upatnieks worked at the Environmental Research Institute of Michigan and was an Adjunct Professor, Electrical and Computer Engineering Department at University of Michigan. From 1993 to 2001 he consulted as Senior Engineer for Applied Optics research and development laboratories in Ann Arbor, Mich. Throughout his professional life Upatnieks has collaborated on research projects with faculty members of the University of Michigan Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science and Department of Mechanical Engineering and Applied Mechanics. Upatnieks has received twenty U.S. patents, for ten of which he is the sole inventor.

Juris Upatnieks is a fellow of the Optical Society (OSA) and of the Society of Photo-Optical Instrumentation Engineers, and foreign member of the Latvian Academy of Sciences. In 1975 Upatnieks was awarded the R. W. Wood Prize by the Optical Society of America. In 1976 he was named Inventor of the Year by the American Association for the Advancement of Invention and Innovation and received the Holly Medal by the American Mechanical Society. In 1999 the Latvian Academy of Science awarded him the Grand Medal for contributions of development of the principles of holography and for promoting its use. Upatnieks was awarded the Walter Cap Prize in 2007 from the Latvian Academy of Sciences and the Latvian Patent Office and Emmett N. Leith Medal in 2010 from the Optical Society of America. Juris Upatnieks is listed in "Who's Who in America."

scopecontent.p: The collection documents Juris Upatnieks' scientific research and output and divided into six series: Correspondence, Subject Files, Proposals, Reports, Lantern Slides, and Laboratory Notebooks.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series (0.75 linear feet) includes correspondence and memoranda for the years 1963-1981 and 1988. Upatnieks' correspondence includes exchanges with American and international scientists discussing scientific research and experiments, as well as manuscripts and published work. The majority of memoranda are Upatnieks' communications on the subject of ongoing research addressed to his colleagues.

The Subject Files series (1 linear foot and oversize folder; 1963-1991) consists of Upatnieks' files dedicated to specific areas of research and activities, manuscripts drafts and printed copies of articles and research papers, often accompanied by correspondence with publishers and notes, and texts of conference presentations. The oversize folder contains blueprints related to Upatnieks' work with the Exxon Foundation. Subject Files are dated between 1967-1968 and 1972-1982.

scopecontent.p: The Reports series (1 linear foot) includes activities, semiannual and final project reports prepared by Juris Upatnieks by himself and/or in cooperation with his colleagues. This series is divided into subseries: Environmental Research Institute of Michigan (ERIM), Institute of Science and Technology (IST), Holotron Corporation, Manuscripts, and U.S. Army. Within each subseries material is organized in chronological order. The majority of material are technical reports. A number of IST reports were prepared by Upatnieks in cooperation with his colleagues, notably with Emmett N. Leith. The majority of ERIM reports were prepared by Upatnieks but some bear names of Upatnieks' colleagues. Manuscripts include drafts of scientific papers and lectures. Memoranda contains reports on ongoing research: descriptions of experiments, findings, further steps, etc. The U.S. Army subseries includes printed reports and papers.

scopecontent.p: The Lantern Slides series (3 linear feet) contains glass slides with images, tables and graphs.

The Laboratory Notebooks series (3 notebooks and 453 MB online) contains digitized versions of Juris Upatnieks's laboratory notebook from January 16, 1963 to December 2, 1982. The notebooks record variables, procedures, and results of experiments related to hologram construction, photography, microscopy, and optics among related topics. Includes Upatnieks’s analyses of results, equations, hand drawn renderings of optical set ups and photographic examples of holograms.
